Forza Motorsports died with real money transactions, leaving a lurching corpse of underwhelming and poorly received products. I didn't expect to like Forza Horizons 4. Horizons is Forza Arcade. Even without playing it most people realize that. But like it I did. And while the setting for 5, I think, is a step down, it's still a fun, albeit massively unrealistic driving game, with loads of vehicular eye candy - without having to shell out 2-5 times the original games cost.

I would still take a Forza game from decades ago with updated physics and graphics over any version of Horizons. But M$ is all about the money... regardless of how it gutted the game design.

Cars handle really well. Fun casual game play. I love how you can make the game as easy or difficultly as you want it to be. Nice low skill floor and extremely high skill ceiling. Really anybody can enjoy this game of all skill levels. Runs super well on all types of computers as well.
So much potential, but the end result is a soulless game for the masses.

As far as casual play goes, FH5 is a perfectly fine game, but for me there is one major glaring issue. The progression system sucks. Instead of starting the game with the lowest class of car and working your way up higher and higher on the performance ladder, the game starts you out with 3 cars that sit in the upper middle section of performance classes. Having cars that start at A and B class ratings invalidates classes C and D outside of experimenting for fun several dozen hours into the game. There's also the wheel spin system of level-up rewards that makes leveling up feel less rewarding. Instead of starting at 5-20k dollar rewards and, as you play, increasing this to higher value cars and greater cash rewards, there is a chance that the level up reward for reaching 20 is a Ferrari FXX and the level reward for reaching level 80 is 20k dollars. It doesn't make me get excited for leveling up as it kinda kills the idea of progressing rewards for progressing levels. All of this led me to feeling like I have "completed" the game 5-10 hours into the game after I got a S2 class supercar through the wheel spin relatively early on. A car that would usually be rewarded in the last few "levels" of other racing games, found its way into my hands as I was still beginning. I felt great that I had gotten so lucky, but after a while it kinda killed my drive to keep playing as much as I had. The game is still fun on a purely driving basis, and I can imagine it is even more fun with friends; but the idea of random progression rewards turns you off, there are probably other options available.

I can't stand the cutscenes in this game. There is a good game behind the cringe for sure, but I just wanted to drive around and play, not look at videos half the time, and since no other button worked to skip the story, Alt-F4 saved the day. 
I bet that most of the almost 150GB used up must be the videos, what a shame.

Lots of flash; very little substance.

Very poor integration with Logitech G29 Wheel/Pedals setup.

Not possible to dial out the absurd amounts of steering oscillation. Checked the (mostly useless) online setup guides and tested their settings however the underlying controller interface is not sufficiently flexible to tune out the yaw without deadening (and substantially degrading) the overall steering performance.

Might work with a controller, however I purchased it in the hope of being able to drive cars in a semi-arcade / semi-simulation mode using a wheel and pedals. During the "refund window" most of the game time was spent yawing from one side of the track to the other and ending up backwards.

Despite lots of bump vibration through the FFB wheel the actual engagement between the vehicle and the track is remote and lacking in any real road feel. If the car behaved more in an arcade mode (i.e. did not enter excessive yaw oscillation at the slightest provocation) this lack of track engagement would not be so much of an issue. However in the current case the lack of track engagement, and the tendency to oscillate wildly at the slightest provocation, the overwhelming sensation is one of lack of control.

This means the game sits uncomfortably between "arcade" and "simulation" modes. It is neither accurate enough to even approach a "simulation" nor unrealistic enough to perform well as an "arcade" style driving game.

Requested a refund.

Looks like it is back to Assetto Corsa (surprisingly good car simulation) or iRacing...

Good luck even logging into this game. Can’t log in on Steam Deck nor Windows PC. If you search online for “Forza Horizon 5 login issues”, you’ll see tons and tons of threads of people complaining about this issue. Despite enjoying it near launch, I cannot recommend this game to anyone.

I won’t be buying future Forza games, both Horizon and Motorsport. If the devs can’t even figure out how to make a login message to appear and actually function, I can’t trust them to make actual good gameplay. There’s so many better racing games out there on PC. Spend your money with a different game development studio.
